content: What is metacognition?

How to read
Learning strategies

content.content: Metacognition is the ability to think about thinking. It is not something that comes naturally. We must learn and practice it like any other knowledge or skill. Skills we need to develop include:

content: Being consciously aware of yourself as a thinker.
Monitoring and controlling your mental processing (e.g., Am I understanding this?)
Accurately judging your level of understanding.

content.content: We have seen Bloom’s taxonomy previously in our Course Manual. We need to learn to apply it to our studying regarding metacognition.

One of the difficult things to learn is the ability to identify what cognitive level a question is asking for. To help with this, we will provide practice questions before the first exam with examples of questions at different Bloom’s cognitive levels. Let’s look at an example.

This question is asking for an answer at least at the Application level. In general, if an question is asking for an explanation It is not looking for simple recall of information, which is what the insufficient answer is providing. For the insufficient answer, the student has memorized some relationships: polar bonds = higher bp and less branching = higher bp. The problem isn’t that these are completely wrong; they just don’t demonstrate a high enough level of understanding. The better answer goes further than this by applying an understanding of how the strength of the IMF and the amount of surface area affect the boiling point.

content: Always solve problems without looking at an example or the solution
Memorize everything you need to memorize
Always ask why, how, and what-if questions
Test understanding by giving “mini-lectures” on concepts
Spend time on chemistry every day
Use the Learning Cycle with Intense Study Sessions
Attend STEM Guide sessions regularly
Aim for 100% mastery, not 90%!
Intellectual Honesty - Don’t fool yourself into thinking you understand something. Require proof.

Intellectual Vulnerability - Don’t worry about someone finding out you don’t know something. It isn’t about showing people how much you know. It is about showing what you don’t know and helping each other grow.
Don’t give up too soon (<15 min.)
Don’t spend too much time (>30 min.)
Preview your reading - what do you want to accomplish in this reading? Learning goals.
Develop questions to be answered by the reading.
Read one paragraph/slide at a time and paraphrase it.
Highlight, make notes, write questions, concept maps, or outlines.
